plugin.name: TEST
plugin.description:
This is just a test plugin. Invoke it passing the String you want to get back and, optionally, the status you want. Return: If you don't specify the status parameters, the return code is 'OK'. The returned message is always the text you pass as parameter (-t/--text)
Example Command Definition (inside the server configuration, in the command section)
check_test : TEST --text $ARG1$ --status $ARG2$
or, using the XML:
<command name="test" plugin_name="TEST"> <arg name="text" value="$ARG1$"/> <arg name="status" value="$ARG2$"/> </command>
Example invocation:
./check_nrpe -n -H myjnrpeserver -c check_test -a 'Hello!critical'

option.description: the message to print
the status to return (ok, warning, critical, unknown)

plugin.name: EXEC
plugin.description:
This plugin is used to execute external (executable) application. (For example, classic Nagios plugins).
Example Command Definition on a Windows OS (inside the server configuration, in the command section)
<command name="check_disk" plugin_name="EXEC" params="-e C:\PROGRA~2\nag-plugins\check_pdm.exe -a '--disk --drive $ARG1$ -w $ARG2$ -c $ARG3$'"/>
Example invocation:
./check_nrpe -n -H myjnrpeserver -c check_disk -a 'c:!70!80'

option.description: path to the executable
executable arguments

plugin.name: CHECK_ORACLE
plugin.description:
This plugin is used to perform various check against an Oracle Database Server. This version is able to perform: * is alive check: checks if the database is alive, connecting to it and performing a 'SELECT SYSDATE FROM DUAL' query. * CACHE HIT RATE check : Check the database for library and buffer cache hit ratios * TABLESPACE check: Check the usage of the given tablespace
**** TO USE THIS PLUGIN, YOU MUST PUT THE ORACLE JDBC THIN DRIVER IN THE DIRECTORY WHERE THIS PLUGIN IS INSTALLED!! **** JDBC OCI DRIVER ARE NOT SUPPORTED!!
Example Command Definitions on a Windows OS (inside the server configuration, in the command section) 1. CHECK IS ALIVE <command name="check_oracle_alive" plugin_name="CHECK_ORACLE" params="--username $ARG1$ --password $ARG2$ -db $ARG3$ --server $ARG4$ --alive"/>
Example invocation: ./check_nrpe -t 20 -n -H myjnrpeserver -c check_oracle_alive -a 'username!password!SID!server'
2. CHECK TABLESPACE
<command name="check_oracle_ts" plugin_name="CHECK_ORACLE" params="--username $ARG1$ --password $ARG2$ -db $ARG3$ --server $ARG4$ --tablespace $ARG5$ -w 70 -c 80"/>
Example invocation: ./check_nrpe -t 20 -n -H myjnrpeserver -c check_oracle_ts -a 'username!password!SID!server!tablespacename'
3. CHECK CACHE
<command name="check_oracle_cache" plugin_name="CHECK_ORACLE" params="--username $ARG1$ --password $ARG2$ -db $ARG3$ --server $ARG4$ --cache -w 70 -c 80"/>
Example invocation: ./check_nrpe -t 20 -n -H myjnrpeserver -c check_oracle_cache -a 'username!password!SID!server'

option.description: Orace SID
Database Server (IP or NAME)
Database Server port (default: 1521)
database username
database password
Check the database for tablespace capacity in ORACLE_SID
warning threshold
critical threshold
Check the database for library and buffer cache hit ratios
Check if the database is alive

plugin.name: CHECK_FILE
plugin.description: This plugin is used to perform various check against files: * checks that a file exists (-f) * checks that a file does not exists (-F) * check file age (requires -f) * check file size (requires -f) * check how many lines of a file contains the given string. You can specify the warning and the critical range. (requires -f) EXAMPLE: -f /path/to/your/file --contains MyString,0:10,11: * check that a string is not inside the file (requires -f)

option.description: The path of the file the must not exist
The path to the file to check
The max age (in seconds) before a warning is rised
The max age (in seconds) before a critical is rised
The min file size (in bytes) before a warning is rised
The min file size (in bytes) before a critical is rised
The string that must be found inside the file in the format STRING,WARNING_RANGE,CRITICAL_RANGE.
The string that must not be found inside the file

plugin.name: CHECK_JMX
plugin.description: WARNING: THIS PLUGIN, REQUIRES JDK 1.5 OR GREATER! This plugin is used to test JMX values. It's based on 'jmxquery' (http://code.google.com/p/jmxquery/) Follows an example. For easiness, the parameters are shown as you would pass them on the command line. EXAMPLE (to monitor pre 7.1 version JBOSS memory usage): -U service:jmx:rmi://127.0.0.1/jndi/rmi://127.0.0.1:1090/jmxconnector -O jboss.system:type=ServerInfo -A TotalMemory -w 731847066: -c 1045495808

Attribute key for -I attribute compound data, for example, 'used'

plugin.name: CHECK_DISK
plugin.description:
This plugins checks the available disk space EXAMPLES The examples will be based upon the following command definition (ini file)
check_disk : CHECK_DISK --path $ARG1$ --warning $ARG2$ --critical $ARG3$
* Example 1 (Windows) The following example will give a WARNING if the free space of the C disk will lower than 10% and a critical if it will be lower than 5%
check_nrpe -H myjnrpeserver -c check_disk -a 'C:!:10!:5'
* Example 2 (Unix) The following example will give a WARNING if the free space of the / file system will lower than 10% and a critical if it will be lower than 5%
./check_nrpe -H myjnrpeserver -c check_disk -a '/!:10!:5'

option.description: The path to check
The used space warning threshold (percent)
The used space critical threshold (percent)

plugin.name: CHECK_USERS
plugin.description:
This plugin checks the number of users currently logged in on the local system and generates an error if the number exceeds the thresholds specified. EXAMPLES The example will be based upon the following command definition (ini file)
check_user : CHECK_USER --warning $ARG1$ --critical $ARG2$
* Example 1 (Windows and Unix) The following example will give a WARNING if the number of logged in users exceeds 10 and a CRITICAL message if the number of users exceeds 20
check_nrpe -H myjnrpeserver -c check_users -a '10:!20:'

option.description: Set WARNING status if more than INTEGER users are logged in
Set CRITICAL status if more than INTEGER users are logged in
